sentences.text: On January 29, 2025, a Bombardier CRJ700 series|Bombardier CRJ700 airliner operating as '''American Airlines Flight 5342''' <!-- Name of flight has been significantly discussed, please see following discussion --> (operated by PSA Airlines as American Eagle (airline brand)|American Eagle){{Efn|name=Eagle}} and a United States Army Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter operating as '''Priority Air Transport 25''' Mid-air collision|collided mid-air over the Potomac River in Washington, D.C.. The collision occurred at 8:47 p.m. at an altitude of about {{Convert|300|ft|-2}} and about one-half mile (800 m) short of runway 33 at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington, Virginia. All 67 people aboard both aircraft were killed in the crash, including 64 passengers and crew on the airliner and the 3 crew of the helicopter. It was the first major U.S. commercial passenger flight crash in nearly 16 years since Colgan Air Flight 3407 in 2009, and the deadliest U.S. air disaster since the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 in 2001.<ref name="AP News 2025" /><!-- There is consensus against including comparisons to other accidents. See: WP:AVILAYOUT-WW -->

Here's what to know |url=https://www.npr.org/2025/01/31/nx-s1-5281946/american-airlines-plane-helicopter-crash-dc |access-date=February 4, 2025 |website=NPR |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Flight 5342 was operated by a 20-year-old Bombardier CRJ700 series|Bombardier CRJ700, a regional jet commonly used for short- to medium-haul flights. It was configured as a CRJ701ER, denoting a slightly higher seating capacity and extended range. Manufactured in September 2004, it bore the manufacturer's serial number 10165 and was Aircraft registration|registered as {{Airreg|N|709PS|.}} PSA Airlines is owned by the American Airlines Group, which is also the parent company of American Airlines. No problems were reported as the plane took off from Wichita on its way to Washington.  Flight 5342's route was only one year old.  For many years, Kansas residents had needed to drive to adjacent Missouri and Oklahoma if they wanted to take long-distance flights.<ref name="Draper" />  A year earlier local leaders had finally convinced American Airlines to establish direct passenger air service from Kansas to the East Coast of the United States|East Coast.<ref name="Draper" />

sentences.text: The helicopter involved was a United States Army|U.S. Army Sikorsky UH-60L Black Hawk registered as {{USAF serial|00|26860}}. The helicopter was configured for use as executive transportation for senior U.S. officials and soldiers, and was flying under the callsign PAT25 indicating a "Priority Air Transport" flight. No senior officials were on board the helicopter. The helicopter was part of the Continuity of Government Plan, with the flight being a routine re-training of aircrew in night flight along the corridor. In emergencies, elements of the US government would use it to evacuate the capital.

sentences.text:
The helicopter had a crew of three Army personnel:
*Captain (United States O-3)|Captain Rebecca Lobach, 28, was the pilot flying and undergoing her annual night flying evaluation. She had accumulated 450 flight time|flight hours at the time of the crash, with 326 on UH-60 type helicopters.
*Chief Warrant Officer 2 Andrew Eaves, 39, was the Check pilot|evaluator for Lobach and was serving as the pilot monitoring who primarily communicated with air traffic controllers. He had 968 flight hours, with 300 on the UH-60.<ref name="CBS: What we know" /><ref name="NTSB Preliminary Report" />

sentences.text: The airliner carried 60 passengers and four crew members: a Pilot in command|captain, a First officer (aviation)|first officer and two flight attendants. The first officer, Samuel Lilley, 28, was the pilot monitoring. He had worked for the airline for two years and accumulated 2,469 flight hours, with 966 on the CRJ.<ref name="NTSB Preliminary Report" />

references.text: <ref name="NTSB Preliminary Report" /> The captain, Jonathan Campos, 34, was the pilot flying and had been with the airline for six years. He had logged 3,950 flight hours, including 3,024 on CRJ-series aircraft, and was a Federal Flight Deck Officer.<ref name="NTSB Preliminary Report" /><ref>{{Cite web |last=Elassar |first=Alaa |last2=Waldenberg |first2=Samantha |last3=Galgano |first3=Taylor |last4=Williams |first4=David |last5=Jackson |first5=Amanda |last6=Coacci |first6=Jessica |last7=Britzky |first7=Haley |last8=Smart |first8=Sara |date=January 31, 2025 |title=A 'bright star' helicopter pilot, a daughter of immigrants and figure skating champions are among DC air collision victims |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2025/01/31/us/dc-plane-crash-victims/index.html |access-date=February 25, 2025 |website=CNN}}</ref>

sentences.text: The airspace around Reagan National Airport is among the world's most complex and closely monitored, with Washington, D.C., Special Flight Rules Area|restrictions on both sides of the Potomac River to protect government buildings in Washington, D.C. Efforts have been made to reduce congestion, but in 2024, Congress approved additional flights. Military helicopter operations further complicated the airspace, including a helicopter corridor which passes within {{Convert|15|ft}} vertically of the approach to runway 33.

sentences.text: On the night of the collision, air traffic control (ATC) staffing was below the typical level for that time and traffic volume, according to a preliminary Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) safety report. Normally, the tower had six controllers: assistant local control, ground control, clearance delivery, local control, and an operations supervisor. Helicopter control and local control operate on different radio frequencies, meaning the crews of Flight 5342 and PAT25 were not able to hear each other's transmissions to the controller, but both could hear the controller's responses.<ref name="NTSB Preliminary Report" />

references.text: <ref name="Ember 2025">{{Cite news |last=Ember |first=Sydney |last2=Steel |first2=Emily |date=January 30, 2025 |title=Staffing Was 'Not Normal' at Air Traffic Tower During Plane Crash |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/30/business/air-traffic-control-staffing-plane-crash.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250130204434/https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/30/business/air-traffic-control-staffing-plane-crash.html |archive-date=January 30, 2025 |access-date=February 1, 2025 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US}}</ref>

<ref name="NTSB Preliminary Report" /> At 9:30 p.m., when air traffic usually decreases, the helicopter control and local control positions are typically combined. However, on the day of the collision, the supervisor merged those positions at 3:40 p.m.<ref name="NTSB Preliminary Report" /> allowing one controller to leave early. The air traffic controllers' union cautioned against assuming the combined role would make conditions unsafe.<ref>{{Cite news |date=February 1, 2025 |title=Investigation into DC plane and helicopter collision looking at potential mistakes in 'no margin for error' situation |url=https://www.cnn.com/2025/01/31/us/black-hawk-helicopter-plane-collision-investigation-wwk/index.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250210104047/https://www.cnn.com/2025/01/31/us/black-hawk-helicopter-plane-collision-investigation-wwk/index.html |archive-date=February 10, 2025 |access-date=February 8, 2025 |publisher=CNN}}</ref>

sentences.text: At 8:43 p.m. Eastern Standard Time|EST (01:43 UTC), as American Airlines Flight 5342 was flying a visual approach to runway 1, it made initial contact with the Reagan National control tower. The controller asked if the crew could switch to runway 33. The crew accepted the request and were subsequently cleared to land on runway 33. The helicopter was about {{Convert|1.1|nmi|lk=in|abbr=~}} west of the Key Bridge (Washington, D.C.)|Key Bridge following Helicopter Route 1 to Helicopter Route 4. At 8:46 p.m., around two minutes before the collision, the controller called the helicopter crew, advising them of a CRJ700, at an altitude of {{Convert|1200|ft}} south of the Woodrow Wilson Memorial Bridge, circling runway 33. The part of the transmission advising that the CRJ was "circling" was not captured by the helicopter's cockpit voice recorder (CVR) and may not have been heard by the helicopter crew. The helicopter crew acknowledged that they had the jet in sight and requested Visual flight rules|visual separation—meaning that they could see and maintain separation from the aircraft on their own—which the controller approved. However, it remains unclear if they had acknowledged the correct aircraft.<!-- Discussion on including aircraft behind 5342 -->{{discuss|Inclusion of WaPo 3D analysis}}

sentences.text: The two aircraft collided at 8:47:59.  The recorded Radar altimeter|radio altitude of the Black Hawk at the time of the collision was {{Convert|278|ft}}. The CRJ700's radio Transponder (aeronautics)|transponder ceased transmitting about {{Convert|2400|ft}} short of Runway 33. The collision was captured by a webcam at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and another video showed a brief trail of fire. Other videos showed that the collision may have damaged the rotor blades of the Black Hawk and the left wing of the CRJ700 as the airliner fell in a left-hand spiral into the water. Witnesses reported that the airliner "split in half" upon impact, while the helicopter crashed upside down near the airliner. A pilot in another aircraft confirmed seeing the crash to an air traffic controller and reported seeing flares from the opposite side of the Potomac as his flight was on Final approach|short final.<ref name="Regan-2025" />

references.text: <ref name="NTSB2025-02-14" /> The helicopter exploded and both aircraft crashed into the Potomac River. sentences.text: Within three hours of the collision, authorities confirmed fatalities. By 2:50 a.m. the following morning, no survivors had been reported, and the search and rescue operations were described as "becoming more grim".

sentences.text: It was the first major commercial passenger flight accident in the U.S. in nearly 16 years, following Colgan Air Flight 3407 in February 2009. It was also the first fatal crash involving American Airlines since American Airlines Flight 587|Flight 587 on November 12, 2001, as well as the first fatal crash of a CRJ700 series aircraft. It was the first crash in the Potomac River since Air Florida Flight 90 on January 13, 1982.

sentences.text: Chief John Donnelly of the District of Columbia Fire and Emergency Medical Services Department (DC FEMS) said emergency responders were notified of an aircraft crash at 8:48 p.m. The first units arrived at the scene at 8:58 p.m., where they discovered the aircraft in the water. DC FEMS was joined by emergency personnel from the Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia, Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority Fire and Rescue Department, United States Coast Guard, Maryland State Police, along with other local, state, and federal agencies. Additionally, several Hornblower Cruises tour boats sailed from the Washington Sailing Marina in Alexandria, Virginia to help with search and rescue operations.

sentences.text: Fireboats and divers were deployed to search for victims and survivors; cold temperatures, strong winds, ice, and murky water hampered rescue efforts. The water temperature near the crash site was recorded at {{Convert|35|F|C}}. On January 30, the rescue operation turned into a recovery mission. By February 4, all bodies had been recovered, including the three soldiers in the helicopter, and all of them were identified by February 5. After the collision, Reagan National Airport suspended all takeoffs and landings, diverting flights to nearby airports, including Dulles International Airport|Dulles, Baltimore/Washington International Airport|Baltimore/Washington, and Richmond International Airport|Richmond. The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority extended Silver Line (Washington Metro)|Silver Line service to help passengers whose flights were diverted to Dulles and dispatched "warming buses" to help relief operations.

sentences.text: The coaches were all former Soviet/Russian figure skaters. Inna Volyanskaya also had competed in pairs while Alexandr Kirsanov competed in ice dancer|ice dance. It was the second time members of the U.S. Figure Skating team died in an aviation accident, after the 1961 crash of Sabena Flight 548 in Belgium. Ever since that crash, a former competitor said, it has been rare to see so many American skaters flying together. Due to the lack of any other direct passenger flights between Wichita and the East Coast, Flight 5342 was the most direct route home for visitors from the Northeastern United States|Northeast.

sentences.text: Among the prominent members of the figure skating community killed in the crash were Evgenia Shishkova and Vadim Naumov, who had won gold medals in pair skating at the 1994 World Figure Skating Championships. The two had a son, Maxim Naumov, who is also a figure skater. He was not on the flight. On March 2, 2025, Naumov would perform alongside others at "Legacy on Ice", a two-hour tribute show held at Capital One Arena in honor of the victims of the crash. His performance was set to "his parents' favorite song", as well as a rendition of Ave Maria (Schubert)|Ave Maria, during which he was joined by other skaters. After the performance, he broke down in tears on the ice.

sentences.text:
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB), the FAA, the United States Department of Defense|U.S. Department of Defense, and the U.S. Army announced they would launch investigations into the collision. 
The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) also stated it would help with the response. However, there were no indications of terrorism or criminal activity.
On the evening of January 30, the flight recorder ("black box") of Flight 5342 was recovered from the wreckage and brought to the NTSB lab for evaluation. The helicopter's flight recorder was recovered on January 31. 


According to the NTSB, at the moment of impact, the helicopter was at a radio altitude of {{Convert|278|ft}}. The NTSB is investigating what altitude the Pressure altimeter|barometric altimeter displayed to the helicopter crew, which was not recorded by the flight recorder. Investigators would normally calculate the barometric altitude displayed to the crew using pressure altitude recorded by the flight recorder, but investigators determined that the data was not valid.

sentences.text: Senators Ted Cruz and Tammy Duckworth addressed questions about the automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast system (ADS-B) which was reportedly turned off on the Black Hawk. Some flight data was being sent from the aircraft but the safety system sends what is considered the most-accurate data. The NTSB confirmed ADS-B was not broadcasting from the helicopter and said they would investigate if there was an equipment malfunction or it was turned off.

sentences.text: President Donald Trump was briefed on the collision shortly after. Shortly after midnight, he wrote on Truth Social questioning the actions of the air traffic controllers and asserting that the situation could have been prevented. He also criticized the helicopter crew for flying too high. Later that morning, Trump released a statement calling the crash a "terrible accident," thanking emergency responders and saying of the victims: "May God bless their souls."<ref name="NBC" /><ref name="Regan-2025" />

sentences.text: Trump alleged that the FAA's diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) goals supported by former presidents Joe Biden and Barack Obama may have been partly to blame for the crash. A policy introduced in 2013 by the Obama administration's FAA that encouraged the hiring of minorities as air traffic controllers was continued by the first Trump administration's FAA. He harshly criticized former transportation secretary Pete Buttigieg, accusing him of infusing diversity at the FAA.<ref name="Sanger 2025" />

sentences.text: Trump criticized the FAA for being open to hiring air traffic controllers with "hearing, vision, missing extremities, partial or complete paralysis, epilepsy, severe intellectual disability, psychiatric disability and dwarfism". This was a policy introduced in 2019 by his own first administration's FAA, which announced a program to allow 20 people with "targeted disabilities" to train at air traffic control centers for air traffic operations careers. Several disabilities such as epilepsy, poor vision, and some mental disorders were still disqualifying for air traffic controller positions per FAA and United States Office of Personnel Management|OPM regulations on Diversity, equity, and inclusion|DEI hires.

sentences.text: response teams at the scene on January 30]]Trump received pushback and criticism for his claims that DEI initiatives were to blame for the crash, including by Buttigieg, who said that Trump's claims were "despicable" and that he should be "leading, not lying". Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota criticized Trump for "blaming this deadly crash on minorities and white women" and that the comments were "disgusting, racist and sexist".<ref name="CNBC Trump lashes" /> Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer of New York also criticized Trump's remarks, calling them "idle speculation". Maryland Senator Chris Van Hollen criticized Trump by stating that he was "making a political show out of this awful tragedy" about the crash.<ref name="BBC" /> Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut stated that Trump was "blaming Black people and blaming women who work at the FAA without any evidence."<ref name="Sangal 2025" /> Representative Chuy García|Jesús "Chuy" García of Illinois stated that Trump was "exploiting disaster to continue to spread racist lies and divisiveness across the country."<ref name="Sangal 2025" /> Sully Sullenberger responded to Trump by stating that "an airplane cannot know or care" about a pilot's race or gender but can only care about "what control inputs are made" and that he was "disgusted" by Trump's comments.<ref name="Regan-2025" /><ref name="BBC-2025" />

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Doherty |first=Erin |date=January 30, 2025 |title='Despicable': Buttigieg fires back at Trump criticisms after deadly plane crash |url=https://www.axios.com/2025/01/30/pete-buttigieg-trump-plane-crash |access-date=January 30, 2025 |website=Axios |quote=Despicable. As families grieve, Trump should be leading, not lying. We put safety first, drove down close calls, grew Air Traffic Control, and had zero commercial airline crash fatalities out of millions of flights on our watch. President Trump now oversees the military and the FAA. One of [Trump's] first acts was to fire and suspend some of the key personnel who helped keep our skies safe. Time for the President to show actual leadership and explain what he will do to prevent this from happening again.}}</ref>

sentences.text: Meanwhile, Trump administration officials agreed with his claim that such policies may have caused the crash. Vice president JD Vance said, "When you don't have the best standards in who you're hiring, it means on the one hand, you're not getting the best people in government. But on the other hand, it puts stresses on the people who are already there." Sean Duffy, the United States Secretary of Transportation, said, "We can only accept the best and the brightest in positions of safety," while Pete Hegseth, the United States Secretary of Defense, said, "The era of DEI is gone at the Defense Department and we need the best and brightest," including in "our air traffic control." Hegseth also said that the helicopter crew was "fairly experienced," and undergoing "routine annual retraining—night flights on a standard [flight] corridor for a Continuity of government|continuity-of-government mission." White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt supported Trump's claim by stating that it was "common sense" to be concerned about potential negative effects of DEI initiatives.<ref name="BBC" />
